noun.description: Exceptional intellectual or creative power or other natural ability.
examples: she was a teacher of genius
Gardner had a real genius for tapping wealth

noun.description: A person who is exceptionally intelligent or creative, either generally or in some particular respect.
examples: one of the great musical geniuses of the 20th century

noun.description: A person regarded as exerting a powerful influence over another for good or evil.
examples: he sees Adams as the man's evil genius
this young man is my good genius, my guardian angel

noun.description: The prevalent character or spirit of something such as a nation or age.
examples: Boucher's paintings did not suit the austere genius of neoclassicism
this book was absolutely genius in parts

origin: Late Middle English: from Latin, attendant spirit present from one's birth, innate ability or inclination, from the root of gignere beget. The original sense spirit attendant on a person gave rise to a sense a person's characteristic disposition (late 16th century), which led to a sense a person's natural ability, and finally exceptional natural ability (mid 17th century).
